comment._content: " The lighting apparatus at the time was described by the builder, Chance Brothers, of Birmingham as the most efficient in the world. It was electric in operation, with the power being produced by two De Meritens magnetos weighing two and a half tons. These were driven by an eight-horse power "Crossley - otto cycle" silent horizontal coal gas engine at 830 rpm. Only one of the de Meritens generators is still in existence: it is owned by the Powerhouse Museum and on display at the Lighthouse. Likewise the original switchboard is owned by the museum but installed the Lighthouse. The Museum have one of the arc lamps, but it is not on display at either venue. The electric apparatus was only used in bad weather. When the weather got really bad the second magneto was brought into operation producing a light of 6,000,000 candelas, the most powerful in the world at the time. In clear weather the illuminate was provided by a gas burner." More here - www.lighthouse.net.au/lights/nsw/Macquarie/Macquarie.htm#... c.1883

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/55167823@N07] Yes. I don't begin to understand the technical stuff, but there are several contemporary newspaper reports which seem to be excited at the then new and probably experimental technology. The lantern - SMH 17/1/1882 p.3 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13503133 The completion - SMH 17/5/1883 p.11 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13535001, including this description of the room above -
"The south wing contains two 8 horse power Otto silent horizontal gas engines for driv- ing two magneto-electro machines, placed in proximity to them for the production of the electric light. From each of these machines insulated conducting cables pass through a "current changer" fixed upon the wall of the engine room, thence up the inside face of the wall of the tower to the light-room, where they are connected with the electric lamp. The current changer is employed for conversion of the electric current from half to full power, and vice versa. The two gas engines and the two mag.-electro machines represent a duplicate system, so that in the event of a breakdown of one of them, the other will be immediately available to replace it."
